I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the country programming review conducted in November 2005, the Government 
(the Government) of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to provide lending support for Gansu Baiyin Urban Development Project (the project). 
Project preparatory technical assistance (TA)1 was included in the ADB assistance program for 
2006 to help the Government prepare the project. ADB fielded a fact-finding mission to the PRC 
for the TA in June 2006. The mission reached agreement with the Government concerning (i) 
the impact and outcome of the project; as well as (ii) the outputs, implementation arrangements, 
consulting  services  needed  and  their  terms  of  reference,  cost  estimates,  and  financing 
arrangement for the TA. The design and monitoring framework of the TA is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Baiyin  City  is  a  medium-sized  city  located  in  Gansu  Province,  one  of  the  12  less 
developed western provinces and autonomous regions targeted by the Government for support 
under the National Strategy for Development of the West (NSDW). The city covers a total land 
area of 21,200 square kilometers (km2) and has a population of 1.74 million (2004). Baiyin City 
has two urban districts: (i) Baiyin District, which has a land area of 1,373 km2, an urban 
population of about 200,000, and where the Baiyin Municipal Government (BMG) is seated; and 
(ii) Pingchuan District, with a land area of 2,106 km2 and an urban population of about 93,000. 
The  two  urban  districts  are  about  60  kilometers  apart.  They  are  connected  by  a  newly 
constructed expressway that is well-integrated with the surrounding national and provincial 
expressway systems, most of which have been built as part of the NSDW. Baiyin City also has 
three agriculture-based rural counties with irrigated agricultural land, mainly along the Yellow 
River, the second-longest river in the PRC. Most of the lands under BMG jurisdiction are state-
owned, uncultivated, undeveloped, mountainous, and without human settlements.   
 
3.    Baiyin City was established in the 1950s under the planned economy, mainly to support 
development and production of Baiyin Nonferrous Metal Corporation, which used to be the 
PRC’s top copper miner, accounting for about one third of national production. Over the past 50 
years, Baiyin City has been developed into an important national center for nonferrous metal 
mining, smelting, and initial processing. The legacy of the planned economy also includes the 
basis for chemical production. Baiyin City is also an important energy center for Gansu Province 
in terms of coal mining and power generation. It has both coal-based thermal power plants and 
hydropower  stations  on  the  Yellow  River.  Rapid  development  of  the  basic  infrastructures, 
supported  under  the  NSDW  over  the  past  few  years,  has  provided  Baiyin,  which  is 
geographically remote and relatively isolated, with the basic means to integrate itself with the 
world market through road, railway, air transport, and telecommunication services. This has 
resulted in steady GDP growth at an average annual rate of 11.4% during the 10th Five Year 
Development Plan period (2001–2005) and a reduction in the proportion of the people living 
below the government poverty line from 12.4% to 10.8%.    
 
4.    Along with continued growth of mining production, the carrying capacity of Baiyin City’s 
urban infrastructure has been stretched to its limit, leading to severe environmental and social 
development problems that affect not only the living standards of the city dwellers but also the 
economic prospects of Baiyin City. The most acute challenge to future development of Baiyin 
City is the need to urgently diversify its economic base in view of the diminishing mining 
resources after decades of exploitation. The two main copper mines of Baiyin Nonferrous Metal

2   
Corporation have already been exhausted and abandoned. Mining of the other associated 
minerals  is  also  on  a  declining  trend,  with  closure  projected  in  less  than  two  decades. 
Thousands of highly skilled workers are looking for new employment opportunities to survive. 
Baiyin City is classified as one of the 18 major “resource-exhausted” mining cities in the PRC, to 
which the newly approved 11th Five Year Development Program has decided to give special 
support,  as  a  national  priority,  in  order  to  facilitate  their  economic  diversification  and 
transformation. The request for ADB lending support for the project is part of the overall support 
provided by the central government to facilitate the economic transformation of Baiyin City.  
 
5.  According to the mayor’s report approved by Baiyin City People’s Congress in February 
2006, BMG has set the goal to achieve continued yet inclusive growth through economic 
diversification and transformation as the foundation to support its long-term and sustainable 
economic and social development. BMG recognizes that success in economic transformation 
should be based on local advantages and market forces. In this context, BMG has decided to 
focus the public interventions on providing an enabling environment to foster and facilitate public 
and  private  investors  as  a  means  of  achieving  economic  transformation,  mainly  through 
extending  and  diversifying  the  existing  production  chains  for  nonferrous  metal  processing, 
chemical production, and agro-processing. Furthermore, in its development plan, BMG has 
accorded high priority to improving provision of district heating service, both by expanding 
service coverage and improving service efficiency for Baiyin District, where many city dwellers 
must rely on low efficiency and highly polluting stoves and small boilers to meet their current 
needs. Based on this strategy, BMG has proposed the project, which will have three major 
components: (i) providing integrated infrastructures, including roads, water supply, wastewater, 
and facilities for power supply, to expand the industrial zone in the southern part of Baiyin 
District as the basis to facilitate economic diversification and transformation; (ii) constructing and 
upgrading urban roads in both Baiyin and Pingchuan districts and improving their interactions 
with the surrounding national and provincial road networks; and (iii) expanding and improving 
the district heating services for Baiyin District. 
 
6.    Promoting  inclusive  growth  in  the  interior  provinces  like  Gansu  has  been  a  major 
strategic thrust of ADB in order to address the regional imbalance in the PRC. In this context, 
ADB has provided several loans and technical assistance to support economic development in 
Gansu  Province.2 All  these  projects  are  under  smooth  implementation.  At  the  same  time, 
processing of the loans is underway for the second Gansu road development project and Gansu 
Heihe hydropower development project, which are included in the assistance program for the 
PRC. The present project will be the first urban development project in Gansu Province financed 
by a multilateral development bank. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The impact of the TA will be to facilitate economic transformation and improve the quality 
of life in Baiyin City. This will be achieved through providing integrated infrastructures for the 
southern part of Baiyin District, improving and upgrading the urban road system, and expanding

and improving the district heating services for Baiyin District. The outcome of the TA will be the 
agreed design for an investment project that is suitable for ADB lending support. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  The  TA  will  provide  consulting  services,  through  engagement  of  international  and 
national  consultants  (the  consultants),  to  help  the  Government  and  BMG  undertake  the 
following major activities:  
 
(i)  Strategic analysis. The consultants will undertake a comprehensive review of 
the urban development plan and economic transformation strategy of Baiyin City 
in the context of the PRC 11th Five Year Development Program, the national 
urbanization strategy, and the NSDW. Based on this review and international 
best  practices,  the  consultants  will  provide  recommendations  for  further 
improving  the  plan  and  strategy,  and  develop  the  project  design  and  the 
monitoring framework for the project. 
(ii)  Economic and financial analyses. The consultants will conduct an economic 
analysis  for  the  project,  including  least-cost  analysis,  where  applicable.  The 
consultants will also review the economic analyses provided by the domestic 
design  institute3 for  the  project  to  ensure  that  these  analyses  meet  ADB 
processing requirements. The consultants will undertake financial analyses of the 
project and of the financial status of those agencies that will be involved in 
implementing  the  project.  The  consultants  will  review  the  financial  analyses 
provided by the design institute for the project to ensure that these meet the 
processing requirements of ADB. 
(iii)  Technical  review.  The  consultants  will  undertake  a  review  of  the  technical 
designs made for all project components and subprojects to ensure that these 
are technically sound, meet all the relevant technical standards and safeguard 
requirements, and are suitable for ADB financing support. Based on this review 
and  national  or  international  best  practices,  the  consultants  will  make 
recommendations for improving the technical design of each project component 
or subproject. 
(iv)  Poverty and socioeconomic analysis. The consultants will help BMG engage a 
qualified survey institute to conduct a household survey and poverty and social 
economic analyses in accordance with ADB requirements. Based on the findings 
and recommendations of the survey and analyses, the consultants will provide 
recommendations to further strengthen the development impact of the project. 
(v)  Environmental  impact  assessment.  The  consultants  will  review  the 
environmental impact assessments (EIA)4 that are prepared for each project 
component or subproject and ensure that all the EIAs meet ADB environmental 
safeguard requirements. Based on review of the EIAs provided, the consultants 
will  provide  recommendations  for  further  improving  the  EIAs  and  help  BMG 
prepare the summary environmental impact assessment in the format required 
by ADB.

4   
(vi)  Resettlement plan. The consultants will help BMG engage a qualified survey 
agency to conduct a survey and prepare the resettlement plan in accordance 
with ADB safeguard requirements.  
(vii)  Institutional review. The consultants will conduct a review of the institutional 
arrangements for the project, and in particular the capacity of each implementing 
agency  with  regard  to  the  project,  and  then  provide  recommendations  for 
improving their capacities to meet the needs of project implementation. Based on 
international best practices, the consultants will also provide recommendations 
on how to strengthen public and private partnerships to accelerate economic 
transformation and improve provision of district heating services in Baiyin City. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The total costs of the TA are estimated to be $700,000 equivalent. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  The  Government  will  finance  the  balance  of  the  TA  costs, 
equivalent to $200,000, through in-kind contributions of office space and facilities, as well as 
salaries for counterpart staff. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance 
any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  BMG will be the Executing Agency for the TA. BMG has already set up an inter-agency 
leading group chaired by the mayor to provide policy guidance and coordination support for the 
TA. Under the guidance of the leading group, BMG has also set up a project management office, 
headed by the vice chairman of the Baiyin Development and Reform Commission, to take care 
of day-to-day operations for the TA and project. The TA will be implemented over a period of 
about 8 months, starting from 20 October 2006 and with a completion date on 30 June 2007. 
 
11.  The TA will require about 10 person-months of international consulting services in the 
fields of urban planning and development (3.5 person-months), financial analysis (2.0 person-
months), poverty and social safeguard (1.5 person-months), economic analysis (1.0 person-
month), environmental impact assessment (1.0 person-month), and institutional analysis (1.0 
person-month). The TA will require about 24 person-months of national consulting services in 
the fields of urban development planning and development (3.0 person-months), economic 
analysis (3.0 person-months), financial analysis (3.0 person-months), resettlement (3.0 person-
months), environmental impact assessment (3.0 person-months), district heating (3.0 person-
months), urban transport (2.0 person-months), poverty and social assessment (2.0 person-
months), clean production (1.0 person-month), and institutional analysis (1.0 person-month). 
The consultants will be engaged through an international consulting firm using the quality and 
cost-based selection method in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. 
The consultants are expected to submit the inception report at the end of the first month of 
fieldwork and the interim report at the end of the second month of fieldwork. They are expected 
to  conduct  workshops  for  participatory  consultation  on  the  draft  documents.  Based  on 
comments received on the interim report, the consultant will proceed with the preparation of the 
final report and submit the draft final report at the end of four months of fieldwork. The outline 
terms of reference for the required consulting services are in Appendix 3. The TA will also 
provide limited office equipment for use during TA implementation (computers, copy machine,

5
fax  machine,  scanner,  etc).  The  equipment  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines and will be handed over to the Government upon completion of the TA. 
 
12.  The TA deliverables will include the feasibility study report for the project, the EIAs and 
summary environmental impact assessment for the project, and the resettlement plan for the 
project. These documents will be published on the websites of ADB and BMG for disclosure and 
dissemination. The outcome of the TA will be subject to evaluation by both ADB and the 
Government in accordance with their respective evaluation policies and requirements. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
13.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for preparing the Gansu Baiyin Urban 
Development Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consulting Service Requirements 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require inputs of 10 person-months from international 
consultants and 24 person-months from national consultants (collectively referred to as the 
consultants). The consultants will be engaged through an international consulting firm and using 
the quality- and cost-based selection method in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants by Asian Development Bank and its Borrowers. The TA will be implemented over 
an  8-month  period.  The  consultants  will  commence  fieldwork  from  October  2006  and  are 
expected to complete required tasks in about 6 months. The final output of the consultants is a 
feasibility study report prepared in accordance with the policies and guidelines of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and which will serve as the basis for formulating an investment 
project for Gansu Baiyin Urban Development Project. The outline terms of reference of the 
consultants are described in the following sections. 
 
B.  Scope of Consulting Services 
 
2.  The inputs of consulting services will focus on, but not necessarily be limited to, the 
following areas: 
 
(i)  Strategic analysis. The consultants will undertake a comprehensive review of 
the urban development plan and economic transformation strategy of Baiyin City 
in  the  context  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China’s  (PRC)  11th  Five  Year 
Development  Program,  the  national  urbanization  strategy,  and  the  National 
Strategy for Development of the West. Based on this review and international 
best  practices,  the  consultants  should  provide  recommendations  for  further 
improving the plan and strategy and develop the project design and monitoring 
framework for the project. 
(ii)  Economic and financial analyses. The consultants will undertake economic 
analyses of the project, including least-cost analysis, where applicable. They will 
review the other economic analyses provided for the project and ensure that 
these meet ADB processing requirements. The consultants will conduct financial 
analyses for the project and review the financial status of the agencies involved 
with regard to project implementation. The consultants will also review the other 
financial  analyses  provided  for  the  project  and  ensure  that  all  the  financial 
analyses meet ADB’s processing requirements. 
(iii)  Technical review. The consultants will review the technical designs of all the 
components under the project to make sure that they are technically sound, meet 
all the relevant technical standards and safeguard requirements, and are suitable 
for ADB financing support. Based on this review, the consultants should also 
make  recommendations  for  improving  technical  designs  of  each  project 
component or subproject based on national or international best practices. 
(iv)  Poverty and socioeconomic analysis. The consultants will help BMG engage a 
qualified  survey  institute  to  conduct  a  household  survey  and  poverty  and 
socioeconomic analyses in accordance with ADB requirements. This includes 
assessing the impact, if any, on ethnic minority groups and the measures needed 
to address such impact. Based on the findings and recommendations of the 
survey and analyses, the consultants should provide recommendations to further 
strengthen the development impact of the project.

10  Appendix 3 
(v)  Environmental  impact  assessment.  The  consultants  will  review  the 
environmental impact assessment (EIA) prepared for each project component 
and make sure that all the EIAs meet ADB requirements. Based on review of the 
EIAs  provided,  the  consultants  will  help  prepare  a  summary  environmental 
impact assessment in the format required by ADB.   
(vi)  Resettlement plan. The consultants will help BMG engage a qualified survey 
agency  to  conduct  a  survey  and  prepare  the  resettlement  plan  (RP)  in 
accordance with ADB requirements.  
(vii)  Institutional review. The consultants will review the institutional arrangements 
for the project. In particular, they will examine the capacity of each implementing 
agency with regard to the project and provide recommendations for improving its 
capacity to meet the needs of project implementation. Based on international 
best  practice,  the  consultants  will  also  provide  recommendations  on  how  to 
strengthen public and private partnerships to accelerate economic transformation 
and improve provision of district heating services. 
 
C.  Outline Terms of Reference for Each Consultant Position 
 
  1.  International Consultants 
 
    a.  International Urban Development Specialist (3.5 person-months) 
 
3.  The international urban development specialist, who should have a background in urban 
transport engineering and planning, will serve as the leader of the team of consultants. He or 
she will guide, coordinate, and supervise the inputs of each individual consultant on the team 
and take responsibility for preparing and finalizing the inception report, interim report, draft final 
report, and final report on behalf of the team. This should include the formulation of project 
design  and  monitoring  framework.  As  an  international  urban  development  specialist,  this 
consultant will give special emphasis to strategic analysis described in clause (i) of paragraph 2 
above,  particularly  in  terms  of  introducing  international  best  practice  for  BMG  to  further 
strengthen the project design. 
 
    b.  International Economist (1.0 person-month) 
 
4.  The international economist, who should have knowledge and experience in economic 
transformation of mining cities, will conduct the economic analysis of each subproject in line with 
ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects and Framework for the Economic and 
Financial Appraisal of Urban Development Sector Projects. Under the overall guidance of the 
international  urban  development  specialist,  this  consultant  will  undertake  a  review  of  the 
economic transformation strategy of Baiyin City. Based on that review and best international 
practices, the consultant should make recommendations for further strengthening the economic 
transformation strategy of Baiyin City in general and the economic rationale of the project in 
particular.  
 
    c.  International Financial Management Specialist (2.0 person-months) 
 
5.  The specialist will conduct a financial analysis of each subproject and an assessment of 
the  financial  performance  of  the  relevant  implementing  agencies  for  revenue-generating 
components  under  the  project  in  accordance  with  the  Framework  for  the  Economic  and 
Financial Appraisal of Urban Development Sector Projects and Guidelines for the Financial 
Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by the Asian Development

Bank. This analysis should include a review of the cost recovery mechanism and tariff structure 
of the district heating services, affordability of heating services for vulnerable groups, impact of 
the subsidy program on the urban poor, and financial management system of the heating 
service provider. 
 
    d.  International Poverty and Social Safeguard Specialist 
      (1.5 person-months) 
 
6.  The  specialist  will  have  two  general  responsibilities:  (i)  to  guide  and  supervise  the 
household survey and conduct poverty and socioeconomic analysis on project impact including 
the impact, if any, on ethnic minority groups, and (ii) to guide and supervise the domestic 
resettlement specialist in formulating the RP for the project in accordance with ADB safeguard 
requirements. As an international consultant, the specialist will assume responsibility to ensure 
that both the presentation and substance of the poverty and socioeconomic analysis and of the 
resettlement plan prepared under the TA meet the quality standards set by ADB for such 
documents. 
 
    e.  International Environment Specialist (1.0 person-month) 
 
7.  The international environment specialist will undertake a review of the EIA prepared for 
each component of the project to ensure that the project will fully meet ADB environmental 
safeguard requirements. Special attention should be given to assessing environmental impacts 
from the production facilities to be promoted in the industrial zone in the southern part of Baiyin 
District under the project. This consultant will also be responsible for preparing and finalizing the 
summary environmental impact assessment in accordance with ADB environmental safeguard 
requirements for timely submission to ADB. As an international consultant, this specialist will 
assume responsibility to ensure that both the presentation and substance of the summary 
environmental impact assessment prepared under the TA meet the quality standards set by 
ADB for such documents. 
 
    f.  International Institutional Specialist (1.0 person-month) 
  
8.  The specialist will review the institutional arrangements made for the project, and in 
particular the capacity of each implementing agency with regard to the project. Based on this

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the People Republic of China: 
The Gansu Baiyin Urban Development Project (the project) will improve the urban environment of Baiyin 
City, thereby enhancing the quality of life and health conditions for 521,900 urban residents. Baiyin is a 
medium-sized city located in Gansu Province, one of the western provinces. Under the centralized 
planning economy, Baiyin had served as one of the most important national bases for nonferrous metal 
mining, but there was little attention and investment devoted to developing municipal services and urban 
infrastructures. This led to severe environmental and social development problems that affect not only the 
living standards of the city dwellers but also the prospects of Baiyin City, which urgently needs to diversify 
its economic base in view of the diminishing mining resources after decades of exploitation. Overall 
benefits of the project will include a more diversified economy to support sustained inclusive growth, as 
well as improved health conditions. The latter will especially benefit the poor, who are most vulnerable to 
environment-related diseases.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Poverty analysis will be carried out to develop pro-poor design, quantify how the project will help to reduce 
poverty, and incorporate other social dimensions within the scope of project implementation. The analysis 
will be conducted with guidance from the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Handbook on Poverty and 
Social Analysis. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
Major stakeholders include national, provincial, municipal, and district governments; roads, industrial park 
management, and the district heating company; as well as project beneficiaries that include utility service 
customers, residents near the roads to be constructed, and villagers residing near the site of the industrial 
park development subproject. Stakeholder analysis, including a household survey, will be conducted 
during implementation of the technical assistance (TA). 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
Three  stakeholder  workshops  will  be  conducted  during  the  TA  implementation.  Findings  from  the 
household survey will be used as inputs. Public consultation will be carried out by the Executing Agency, 
local government officials, design institutes, and others during preparation of the feasibility study, poverty 
and social assessment, environmental impact assessment, and resettlement plan (RP).

The ADB Policy on Gender and Development will be followed by the Executing Agency during project 
preparation and implementation. Gender aspects will be incorporated into the design and implementation 
of some project components, particularly in relation to the employment opportunities and RP.
